channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Canada’s New Leadership Reverses Course on Climate Change
item.description: The new prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has moved climate-change policy to the top of the country’s political agenda after it spent nearly a decade as an afterthought.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with high school students in Ottawa after an information session on climate change.

item.title: Britain Adopts Black Friday With an All-American Frenzy
item.description: Some retailers are trying to dial back, because for a nation that prides itself on decorum, last year was ugly; or, a typical American Black Friday.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Shoppers wrestling over a television on Black Friday at an Asda superstore in Wembley, North London, last year. Asda said it would not participate in this year's Black Friday shopping frenzy.

item.title: Human Rights Advocacy Costs a Canadian a Shot at Miss World
item.description: Miss Canada, Anastasia Lin, was denied a visa to attend the international pageant, apparently because she is outspoken about human-rights abuses in the country of her birth.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miss Canada, otherwise known as Anastasia Lin, 25, in her pageant dress in Toronto. Ms. Lin was denied a Chinese visa to attend the international pageant this week on the southern Chinese island of Hainan.

item.title: Portugal’s New Premier Takes Office, Facing Financial Balancing Act
item.description: The new government of António Costa, the Socialist leader and a former mayor of Lisbon, brings to an end to almost two months of political instability.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Russian-Turkish Tensions Heat Up Over Downed Warplane
item.description: Russia was looking at ways to curb commercial ties and investment projects, possibly including the deal to build a gas pipeline through Turkey.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephane De Sakutin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and President François Hollande of France met in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Pope, in Kenya, Calls for Compassion for Poor and Nurturing of Youth
item.description: Francis also said the need for dialogue between religions was “essential” during a meeting on Thursday on his first official trip to Africa.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Catholic priests and worshipers on Thursday attending a Mass by Pope Francis in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
item.description: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A single light illuminated a room Wednesday during a blackout in the city of Simferopol, Crimea.

item.title: China to Build Up Presence in Djibouti Amid Military Overhaul
item.description: As reports emerged of plans for a major reorganization of its military, China said a facility in Djibouti would serve to resupply its naval ships taking part in antipiracy missions.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A People's Liberation Army training drill near Beijing last year. China said on Thursday that it would build a logistics facility in Djibouti, in a sign of the growing reach of its navy.

item.title: Britain and Germany Test Support for Stronger Steps Against ISIS
item.description: The leaders’ steps came amid efforts by the French president this week to rally his allies against the threat posed by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain released on Thursday a 36-page document, detailing a plan to try to tackle the threat posed by the Islamic State diplomatically as well as militarily.

item.title: Visiting Kunduz, a Taliban Target, Afghan Leader Urges Security Overhaul
item.description: Reacting to Kunduz city’s recent fall to the Taliban, President Ashraf Ghani announced the dismissal of the provincial intelligence chief and an overhaul of the security leadership.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: On High Alert Since Paris Attacks, French Gear Up for Climate Talks
item.description: Security analysts say that since France has been locked down under a state of emergency since the Nov. 13 attacks, absorbing the extra burden may be easier.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Gendarmes on patrol in Paris this week. Nearly 3,000 extra police officers will be deployed to protect a projected 50,000 visitors and 147 heads of state descending on the city beginning on Sunday for climate talks.

item.title: Belgium Lowers Terror Attack Alert Level for Brussels
item.description: The re-assessment came five days after officials waned that the risk of a Paris-style terrorist attack on Brussels was “serious and imminent.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: People were back in numbers on Thursday on the main commercial street in Brussels.

item.title: Pakistani Police Investigate Fire at Christian TV Station
item.description: Employees of Gawahi TV said the fire at their office in Karachi was set deliberately, and that computers were destroyed or stolen and religious books were burned.
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ

item.title: Burkina Faso, a Year After Uprising, Will Head to Polls
item.description: Heavy turnout is expected, and observers will fan out across the West African country to guard against irregularities in presidential and parliamentary voting.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: HERVÉ TAOKO
item.media:description: Zéphirin Diabré, a businessman and former official with the United Nations Development Program, at a campaign rally for his presidential bid in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Time Before Iraq Invasion Holds Lessons for Fight Against ISIS
item.description: The constellation of alliances and perceived national interests has shifted over the past 12 years.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Press Association, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain addressed the House of Commons on Thursday to persuade wavering lawmakers to authorize airstrikes against Islamic State forces in Syria.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: To Beat Mugabe, Zimbabwe Needs a United Opposition
item.description: If Joice Mujuru joins forces with other opposition leaders, there is a chance they could oust Robert Mugabe together.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER NOYES

item.title: Berlin Journal: Migrants Arriving in Germany Face a Chaotic Reception in Berlin
item.description: A new asylum processing center is mired in long delays with people huddling in the cold for days awaiting their turn as the city government, hobbled by cuts, struggles to cope.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and KATARINA JOHANNSEN
item.media:description: Volunteers served migrants outside the State Office for Health and Social Affairs in Berlin last month. Hundreds gather there each day for a chance to register for asylum.

item.title: China to Release Journalist Gao Yu From Prison Over Illness
item.description: Ms. Gao had been convicted of leaking a Communist Party document that laid out plans for a campaign against liberal Western ideas.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: China Says It Has Detained 2 Dissidents Sent Back by Thailand
item.description: Chinese public security officials told a state-run newspaper that the men were in detention on illegal migration charges.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Xi Jinping Announces Overhaul of China’s Military Forces
item.description: The president said the changes would take years and were essential to creating a more nimble People’s Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, at the lectern, with People's Liberation Army honor guards in Beijing in September.
